make out.translation[0].definitions[0].d: to be just able to see or hear something
make out.translation[0].definitions[0].e: He could just make out a dark shape moving towards him.
I couldn’t make out what he was saying.
make out.translation[0].definitions[1].d: to understand something, especially the reason why something has happened
make out.translation[0].definitions[1].e: As far as I can make out, he has never been married.
I couldn’t make out what I had done to annoy her.
make out.translation[0].definitions[2].d: to understand someone’s character and the way they behave
make out.translation[0].definitions[2].e: Stuart’s a strange guy – I can’t make him out at all.
make out.translation[0].definitions[3].d: to write something such as a bill or cheque
make out.translation[0].definitions[3].e: She was making out a list of people to invite.
The book gives advice on making out a will.
Make the cheque out to ‘Grays Ltd’.
make out.translation[0].definitions[4].d: to say that something is true when it is not
make out.translation[0].definitions[4].e: The situation was never as bad as the media made out.
She always tried to make out that I was wrong and she was right.
He makes me out to be some sort of idiot.
make somebody/something out to be something
make out.translation[0].definitions[5].d: to find good reasons that prove something or show why you need something
make out.translation[0].definitions[5].e: We made out a case for hiring another assistant.
make out.translation[0].definitions[6].d: to succeed or progress in a particular way
make out.translation[0].definitions[6].e: How did you make out this morning?
make out.translation[0].definitions[7].d: to kiss and touch someone in a sexual way
make out.translation[0].definitions[8].d: to get or win a lot of money
make out.translation[0].definitions[8].e: The lawyers made out like bandits.
make out.translation[1].definitions[0].d: to write a cheque, bill etc so that it can be paid to someone
make out.translation[1].definitions[0].e: Can you make the cheque out to me?
make out.translation[1].definitions[1].d: to succeed or progress in a particular way
make out.translation[1].definitions[1].e: How did you make out at the interview?
